title: Obama makes March Madness predictions after Trump declined
title_page: Obama makes March Madness predictions after Trump declined | Daily Mail Online
text:
March Madness fans working on their office pool brackets got a last minute assist from former President Barack Obama, after the current office holder declined to participate in the annual college sports tradition.
Obama on Wednesday released his picks for the NCAA men's and women's basketball tournaments, one day before tip-off for the first games on Thursday.
The avid basketball fan predicts that Duke University and the University of North Carolina will meet in the men's championship game, something that has never previously happened for the arch-rival college ball powerhouses located a mere 10 miles from each other in central North Carolina.
Obama predicts number six nationally ranked UNC will best number seven Duke in the final.
Obama predicts UNC will best Duke in the men's final. The arch-rivals have never met in an NCAA championship game
Obama made March Madness prediction brackets an annual tradition while he was in the White House (file photo)
The former president also predicts the UConn team to best Notre Dame in the NCAA women's basketball championship
For the women's tournament, Obama calls number one nationally ranked University of Connecticut to beat number two Notre Dame in the championship game.
The former president predicts a few upsets in the men's first round, including number 10 seed VCU over seventh seeded St. Mary's, and 10th seeded Wichita State besting number seven seed Dayton.
OBAMA'S MARCH MADNESS BRACKET RECORD
YEAR 2016 2015 2014 2013 2012 2011 2010 2009 OBAMA'S CHAMPION PICK Kansas Kentucky Michigan State Indiana UNC Kansas Kansas UNC ACTUAL CHAMPION Villanova Duke UConn Louisville Kentucky UConn Duke UNC
Despite Obama's fandom, which made his annual bracket release an anticipated tradition while in the White House, as president he was a middling hand at bracket predictions.
In eight years as president, Obama picked the final champion correctly only once: UNC in 2009.
If his prediction for them to win is correct again this year, it would be UNC's sixth NCAA championship title.
Obama's annual bracket picks became an annual tradition while he was in the Oval Office, often followed by appearances on ESPN to discuss his picks.
Last month, ESPN said it approached President Donald Trump about submitting a March Madness bracket, but that the current administration had 'respectfully declined.'
